linkTarget.anchoringText: Conventional PDC cutters drill by shearing the formation. Conical diamond elements (CDEs) drill formations by combining shearing and plowing rock-destruction mechanisms. The cutters’ unique conical geometry combined with ultrathick polycrystalline diamond (PCD) layer (Fig. 1) provide superior impact strength and wear resistance.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: The CDEs’ conical geometry and ultrathick PCD layer provide multiple advantages over conventional PDC cutting elements.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The CDEs’ conical geometry and ultrathick PCD layer provide multiple advantages over conventional PDC cutting elements.

linkTarget.anchoringText: These conical elements are strategically placed across the bit face to contribute for a step change in drilling performance. These elements are placed from gauge to bit center (Figure 2) using a finite-element-analysis (FEA) -based modeling system. The new design strengthens the overall cutting structure compared with conventional fixed cutter PDC bits. The key performance objectives were to

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: A bit can include PDC cutters with CDE backups (left) or be fully equipped with CDEs (right).

formatted-caption.caption-text: A bit can include PDC cutters with CDE backups (left) or be fully equipped with CDEs (right).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: A bit can include PDC cutters with CDE backups
or be fully equipped with CDEs

linkTarget.anchoringText: To ensure robustness of the CDE, significant research and development were invested to refine the design and manufacturing processes to optimize the element’s material properties. Although the CDEs are made of polycrystalline diamond similar to conventional PDC cutters, they are manufactured using proprietary equipment to achieve the necessary pressures to produce their significant impact strength and wear resistance. Compared with a conventional PDC cutter, a CDE is approximately twice as thick at the conical tip (Figure 3).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Ultrathick diamond table provides superior impact strength/wear resistance.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Ultrathick diamond table provides superior impact strength/wear resistance.

linkTarget.anchoringText: To quantitatively measure the CDE’s impact strength compared with a conventional PDC cutter, a series of laboratory tests were conducted using a single-cutter device. Both elements were dropped onto a hardened steel block with an impact force of 18,000 lbf [80,000 N]. The experiment would simulate transitional drilling of a PDC bit exiting soft shale then encountering hard limestone at an ROP of 60 ft/hr. The conventional PDC cutter suffered catastrophic failure on first impact which completely destroyed the cutter’s sharp edge (Figure 4).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: The PDC cutter failed on the first impact; the CDE survived 100 impacts without damage (left).

formatted-caption.caption-text: The PDC cutter failed on the first impact; the CDE survived 100 impacts without damage (left).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Using data from both tests, hard-material scientists determined the CDE’s thick diamond table essentially doubles its impact strength and provides approximately 25–30% more wear resistance compared with a conventional premium PDC cutters (Figure 5). These properties suggest CDE bits have vast potential to improve run lengths and penetration rates in impact-prone applications including hard interbedded formations and conglomerates, in transitional drilling, and in formations that contain pyrite and chert.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: The CDE’s thick diamond table produces greater wear resistance and impact strength.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The CDE’s thick diamond table produces greater wear resistance and impact strength.

linkTarget.anchoringText: After laboratory testing, engineers wanted to determine how the CDE would fail difficult rock formations. An FEA-based modeling system was used to avoid costly and time-consuming field trials. The virtual testing determined the CDE would produce concentrated point loading that can fail high-compressive strength formations more efficiently than conventional PDC cutters (Figure 6).

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: FEA modeling shows CDE (right) produces higher stress levels, which fracture high-compressive-strength rock more efficiently compared with a conventional PDC cutter (left).

formatted-caption.caption-text: FEA modeling shows CDE (right) produces higher stress levels, which fracture high-compressive-strength rock more efficiently compared with a conventional PDC cutter (left).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: produces higher stress levels, which fracture high-compressive-strength rock more efficiently compared with a conventional PDC cutter

linkTarget.anchoringText: When developing the new CDE bits, designers surmised that the plowing action created by the conical diamond element would produce less torque than a conventional PDC cutter that aggressively shears formation. To test the hypothesis, extensive laboratory testing was performed that confirmed that conical elements drill with an average of 26% less torque than conventional PDC cutters (Figure 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: As ROP increases, a CDE (green) drills with 26% less torque compared with conventional PDC cutters (gray), providing better directional response and smoother toolface control

formatted-caption.caption-text: As ROP increases, a CDE (green) drills with 26% less torque compared with conventional PDC cutters (gray), providing better directional response and smoother toolface control

linkTarget.anchoringText: Unwanted lateral and axial vibration that occurs during the wellbore construction process reduces drilling efficiency. The undesirable drillstring harmonics require more mechanical specific energy input to the system, which can lower ROP and reduce run lengths. Engineers used FEA modeling to compare a standard PDC cutter with the conical diamond element. Results showed that the CDE has a more balanced force profile when both are placed across the bit face (Figure 8).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: FEA modeling shows the resultant lateral force of CDE is much lower than a PDC cutter when both are placed across a cutting structure

formatted-caption.caption-text: FEA modeling shows the resultant lateral force of CDE is much lower than a PDC cutter when both are placed across a cutting structure

linkTarget.anchoringText: In a bit design exercise, modeling confirmed the balanced profile equates to less lateral force per cutting element on CDE bits compared with conventional PDCs mitigating shock and vibration (Figure 9). The increased bit/BHA stability would translate into higher ROP and footage totals while prolonging the operating life of costly downhole measurement/steering tools. The reduction in vibration using CDE bits was then confirmed in a South Texas field test (Figure 10).

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: In a simulated drilling through 30,000-psi limestone at 18,000-lbf WOB, the CDE bit displayed 86% lower lateral vibration than a conventional PDC bit (left).

formatted-caption.caption-text: In a simulated drilling through 30,000-psi limestone at 18,000-lbf WOB, the CDE bit displayed 86% lower lateral vibration than a conventional PDC bit (left).

linkTarget.anchoringText: In a bit design exercise, modeling confirmed the balanced profile equates to less lateral force per cutting element on CDE bits compared with conventional PDCs mitigating shock and vibration (Figure 9). The increased bit/BHA stability would translate into higher ROP and footage totals while prolonging the operating life of costly downhole measurement/steering tools. The reduction in vibration using CDE bits was then confirmed in a South Texas field test (Figure 10).

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: In the field, the CDE bit produced 53% and 37% less lateral/axial vibrations, respectively.

formatted-caption.caption-text: In the field, the CDE bit produced 53% and 37% less lateral/axial vibrations, respectively.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Laboratory testing revealed the concentrated point loading created by the CDE’s unique conical geometry would generate larger drill cuttings at the rig site. In field tests, CDE bits produced a significant amount of 2-mm cuttings by volume when compared with cuttings produced by conventional PDC bits in similar formations (Figure 11).

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: The standard PDC produced small cuttings when drilling limestone with high chert content (left). The CDE bit generated larger cuttings in the same formation, which greatly enhanced formation evaluation (right)

formatted-caption.caption-text: The standard PDC produced small cuttings when drilling limestone with high chert content (left). The CDE bit generated larger cuttings in the same formation, which greatly enhanced formation evaluation (right)

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: The standard PDC produced small cuttings when drilling limestone with high chert content
The CDE bit generated larger cuttings in the same formation, which greatly enhanced formation evaluation

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Thailand, an operator wanted to exploit the Sin Phu Horm (SPH) gas field located in the province between city of Udon Thani and Khon Kaen of northeastern Thailand (Figure 12). SPH gas reservoirs are mostly the Permian Pha Nok Khao (PNK) carbonates. The reservoir formation was deposited in early to mid Permian as an inverted-horst platform shelf carbonate. To the east and west of the horst are deep grabens containing thick open marine siliciclastic sediments of the same age.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: General location of the SPH field in Thailand.

formatted-caption.caption-text: General location of the SPH field in Thailand.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Achieving the drilling objectives to complete the well on time was a priority. Offset wells suffered from hole stability issues at shallow depths. Therefore, the best strategy for optimizing performance and minimizing drilling risk involves drilling the interval with minimum steering requirements and moving all directional requirements to a deeper interval. However the subject section comprised hard, dense, and abrasive sandstone, which posed steering difficulties, shock and vibration, and damage to the bit and BHA. With this strategy, the main challenge now is to achieve directional requirement (Figure 13), steering the well through hard, dense, and abrasive sandstones.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Directional well profile in meters, dogleg severity (DLS) of 3.2°/30 m, and maximum DLS of 4.2°/30 m reached.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Directional well profile in meters, dogleg severity (DLS) of 3.2°/30 m, and maximum DLS of 4.2°/30 m reached.

linkTarget.anchoringText: A rock-strength identification program was run on offset wells to determine the formations unconfined compressive strength (UCS) (Figure 14). This software package utilizes the input from from sonic, gamma ray, density, porosity, and mud logs to calculate the unconfined compressive strength. The study indicated that the formation drilled is mainly sandstone with UCS ranging from 18,000 to 21,000 psi with very high abrasion index and heavy impact indices.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Rock strength program with lithology diagram pegged sandstone and limestone with UCS between 18,000 and 21,000 psi and peaks up to 30,000 psi.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Rock strength program with lithology diagram pegged sandstone and limestone with UCS between 18,000 and 21,000 psi and peaks up to 30,000 psi.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The mineralogy chart (Figure 15) from the subject well indicated that illite and quartz content were higher throughout the interval. The presence of these minerals depicts how hard the formation was.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Mineralogy chart indicating that illite and quartz contents were higher throughout the interval.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mineralogy chart indicating that illite and quartz contents were higher throughout the interval.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Roller cone TCI bits were the primary tool choice in the first two offset wells drilled in this field, which were vertical wells. The shorter interval drilled and reliability issues related to high total bit revelotuions, and torque symptoms caused numerous trips for tool changeout (Figure 16). However, in the next two offset wells, PDC bits were tried and resulted in multiple trips along with steering difficulties such as toolface fluctuations and high vibrations (Figure 17). The section TD was much shallower than the subject well.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: 4 TCI and 2 PDC to drill a vertical 8 ½” interval

formatted-caption.caption-text: 4 TCI and 2 PDC to drill a vertical 8 ½” interval

linkTarget.anchoringText: Roller cone TCI bits were the primary tool choice in the first two offset wells drilled in this field, which were vertical wells. The shorter interval drilled and reliability issues related to high total bit revelotuions, and torque symptoms caused numerous trips for tool changeout (Figure 16). However, in the next two offset wells, PDC bits were tried and resulted in multiple trips along with steering difficulties such as toolface fluctuations and high vibrations (Figure 17). The section TD was much shallower than the subject well.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: PDC bit was deployed in shallow intervals with less directional work (mainly 8-bladed bit).

formatted-caption.caption-text: PDC bit was deployed in shallow intervals with less directional work (mainly 8-bladed bit).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Although it was evident the PDC’s shearing cutting action was the most effective rock failure mechanism and had the greatest potential to deliver higher ROP and extended run lengths compared with TCI, the durability of conventional fixed-cutter bits was not sufficient. The operator requested the provider implement a highly durable PDC bit (Figure 18) in the subject well as contingency option, the bit drilled only 407 ft [124 m] before being pulled out for poor ROP. On surface, the cutting structure showed initiation of ringout in the shoulder area.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Conventional PDC bit showing initiation of ringout in the shoulder area.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Conventional PDC bit showing initiation of ringout in the shoulder area.

linkTarget.anchoringText: To reduce the number of trips and improve the steerability, an innovative bit was designed with strategically positioned CDEs and conventional PDC cutters across the entire cutting structure from bit center to gauge (Figure 19). The bit’s cutting structure was modeled using proprietary simulation software, and analysis indicated that the new CDE bit type would improve performance and withstand the shock and vibration incurred while drilling the hard sandstone and limestone formation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: The 8½ in CDE bit included 52 PDC cutters strengthened by 19 strategically positioned CDEs.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The 8½ in CDE bit included 52 PDC cutters strengthened by 19 strategically positioned CDEs.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The 8½-in hybrid CDE bit was run on Well 4 following a TCI roller cone bit used to drill out the casing shoe (Figure 20). After completing the drillout run, the objective was to finish the remainder of the hole section using only PDC bits. Two CDE bits were run and demonstrated significant improvement in ROP, toolface control, and total meterage drilled. The CDEs worked as planned and protected the conventional PDC cutters from impact damage while drilling the hard sandstone intervals.

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: The three wells were drilled as follows: TCI bits only (Well 1), PDC and TCI (Well 2), only PDC (Well 3), and two hybrid CDE bits (a TCI and a conventional PDC bit), which produced the required improvements in run lengths and achieved the directional plan with smoother steerability (Well 4).

formatted-caption.caption-text: The three wells were drilled as follows: TCI bits only (Well 1), PDC and TCI (Well 2), only PDC (Well 3), and two hybrid CDE bits (a TCI and a conventional PDC bit), which produced the required improvements in run lengths and achieved the directional plan with smoother steerability (Well 4).
